image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from North Carolina; born in Elkin, Surry County, N.C., August 16, 1896; educated in the public schools; attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1915 and 1916 and Yale University in 1916 and 1917; served in the United States Navy from May 1917 until discharged as an ensign in June 1919; in July 1919 started working in the textile mills of Chatham Manufacturing Co. at Winston-Salem, N.C., and retired in 1955 as chairman of the board of directors; also owned and operated a farm near Elkin, N.C.; member of the Woolen Wage and Hour Board, Washington, D.C., in 1939; served as a member of the State Board of Conservation and Development and as county commissioner of Forsyth County; served in the Navy from February 14, 1942, to November 25, 1945, with combat duty in the Southwest Pacific; unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination in 1946 to the Eightieth Congress; elected as a Democrat to the Eighty-first and to the three succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1949-January 3, 1957); unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1956; died in Durham, N.C., February 5, 1957; interment in Salem Cemetery, Winston-Salem, N.C.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Christian, Ralph J. "The Folger-Chatham Congressional Primary of 1946." The North Carolina Historical Review 53 (Winter 1976): 25-53.

researchRecord.name: 1776-1956, 61 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers document Richard Thurmond Chatham's role as president of Chatham Manufacturing Company (textiles), and congressman (1949-1957). His general correspondence files and subject files contain letters and papers about his campaigns for Congress and his work in Washington. A finding aid for the papers is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: 1898-1956, 9 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers include correspondence, bills and receipts, and other materials relating to Richard Thurmond Chatham, chiefly from 1949-1956. Most materials touch on Richard Chatham's legislative career only superficially; very few deal directly with legislation or other issues in which Richard Chatham was involved. The files include a mixture of personal materials (clubs; travel, including hunting and fishing expeditions; some family materials; interests in birding, gardening, farming; life in Washington, D.C.), business materials (Chatham Manufacturing Company, land deals, and other investments), and legislative/political materials (mostly minor references to various issues and elections, except for 1954-1956 when there are files on foreign affairs).
